questions.questionText: What is a valid reason for a seller to terminate an agency agreement?
options: Lack of trust in the agent
Agent’s unethical behavior
Unfavorable market conditions
Agent’s refusal to lower fees
questions.correctAnswer: Agent’s unethical behavior
questions.explanation: Ethical violations justify terminating an agency agreement.

questions.questionText: When is a listing firm entitled to a commission?
options: When marketing efforts are initiated
When an offer is accepted
When a transaction closes
When a ready, willing, and able buyer is found
questions.correctAnswer: When a ready, willing, and able buyer is found
questions.explanation: A firm earns commission upon finding a buyer who meets the seller's terms.

questions.questionText: What constitutes a breach of a listing contract?
options: Seller declines all offers
Seller fails to disclose a defect
Seller uses another firm during the contract period
Seller delays showings due to personal reasons
questions.correctAnswer: Seller uses another firm during the contract period
questions.explanation: Engaging another firm during the contract breaches exclusivity.

questions.questionText: What must a licensee disclose to all parties in a transaction?
options: Seller’s reason for selling
Personal opinions about property value
Material adverse facts about the property
Previous owner’s contact information
questions.correctAnswer: Material adverse facts about the property
questions.explanation: Licensees are required to disclose material adverse facts.

questions.questionText: What does “time is of the essence” in a contract mean?
options: Deadlines are flexible
Deadlines must be strictly met
Delays are permissible with notice
Parties must negotiate new deadlines
questions.correctAnswer: Deadlines must be strictly met
questions.explanation: Time is of the essence means all deadlines are firm and binding.

questions.questionText: Under what condition is earnest money refundable?
options: Buyer changes their mind
Seller delays closing
Contract is terminated per contingency terms
Buyer’s financing falls through without notice
questions.correctAnswer: Contract is terminated per contingency terms
questions.explanation: Earnest money is refundable if contingencies are not met.

questions.questionText: When is a counter-offer valid?
options: Once drafted by the seller
After being reviewed by a broker
When signed and delivered to the initiating party
Upon verbal agreement
questions.correctAnswer: When signed and delivered to the initiating party
questions.explanation: A counter-offer must be signed and delivered to be valid.

questions.questionText: What is required for a buyer to waive a financing contingency?
options: Seller’s approval
Written notice to the seller
Verification of funds
Loan pre-approval
questions.correctAnswer: Written notice to the seller
questions.explanation: Waiving contingencies requires written notice.

questions.questionText: What is a seller’s obligation under the “Seller Cooperation with Marketing Efforts” clause?
options: To ensure the property is staged
To provide access to necessary documents
To host open houses
To accept all reasonable offers
questions.correctAnswer: To provide access to necessary documents
questions.explanation: Sellers must provide necessary documents for marketing and transaction.

questions.questionText: When can a firm hold earnest money?
options: If authorized in the listing contract
If requested by the buyer
Only with a separate escrow agreement
Upon receipt of the signed offer
questions.correctAnswer: If authorized in the listing contract
questions.explanation: Holding earnest money must be authorized in the contract.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of a WB-44 Amendment to Offer to Purchase?
options: To notify the other party of a defect
To propose changes to an accepted offer
To counter an offer
To terminate a contract
questions.correctAnswer: To propose changes to an accepted offer
questions.explanation: Amendments modify terms of an accepted offer.

questions.questionText: What happens if a licensee provides legal advice to a client?
options: It strengthens the client relationship
It fulfills their duty as a professional
It violates Wisconsin administrative code
It ensures proper contract interpretation
questions.correctAnswer: It violates Wisconsin administrative code
questions.explanation: Licensees are prohibited from providing legal advice.

questions.questionText: What must a licensee do when modifying an approved form?
options: Use blank lines provided or an addendum
Cross out provisions without concern for legibility
Use handwritten changes exclusively
Recreate the form to accommodate new terms
questions.correctAnswer: Use blank lines provided or an addendum
questions.explanation: Modifications must use the blank lines or an addendum.

questions.questionText: When is a WB-45 Cancellation Agreement and Mutual Release appropriate?
options: To counter a buyer’s offer
To amend contract terms
To terminate a contract and release claims
To notify of an issue with earnest money
questions.correctAnswer: To terminate a contract and release claims
questions.explanation: It cancels contracts and releases claims.

questions.questionText: What is the effect of a buyer’s failure to meet an inspection deadline?
options: The seller must renegotiate terms
The buyer waives the inspection contingency
The contract automatically terminates
The seller can cure defects
questions.correctAnswer: The buyer waives the inspection contingency
questions.explanation: Missing deadlines results in waiving contingencies.

questions.questionText: How can a seller terminate a buyer’s financing contingency?
options: By rejecting the offer
By delivering a notice of termination after a missed deadline
By denying access to the property
By issuing a counter-offer
questions.correctAnswer: By delivering a notice of termination after a missed deadline
questions.explanation: Missing financing contingency deadlines allows termination.

questions.questionText: What is a broker’s duty under the “Buyer's Financial Capability” clause?
options: Confirm buyer’s credit score
Evaluate buyer’s financial statements
Verify buyer’s loan commitment
Ensure proper documentation is submitted
questions.correctAnswer: Ensure proper documentation is submitted
questions.explanation: Brokers ensure proper documentation but don’t evaluate finances.

questions.questionText: What happens if a property is damaged after acceptance but before closing?
options: The buyer must proceed without adjustments
The seller repairs damage if it’s ≤5% of purchase price
The contract is immediately void
The buyer is entitled to full compensation
questions.correctAnswer: The seller repairs damage if it’s ≤5% of purchase price
questions.explanation: The seller repairs damage up to 5% of the purchase price.

questions.questionText: When can a listing firm claim a commission for a protected buyer?
options: If the buyer contacts the seller after the listing expires
If the protected buyer views the property
If the buyer enters into a contract during the protection period
If the seller refuses to relist with the same firm
questions.correctAnswer: If the buyer enters into a contract during the protection period
questions.explanation: Protected buyers result in commission if a contract occurs during protection.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of a WB-41 Notice Relating to Offer to Purchase?
options: To change contract terms upon delivery
To notify the other party of a specific event or decision
To act as an amendment to the contract
To terminate the contract if signed by both parties
questions.correctAnswer: To notify the other party of a specific event or decision
questions.explanation: The WB-41 is used for notifications, not contract modifications.

questions.questionText: What is the primary role of the Real Estate Examining Board (REEB)?
options: Enforcing ethical standards
Creating educational programs for licensees
Approving real estate forms and managing disciplinary actions
Mediating disputes between buyers and sellers
questions.correctAnswer: Approving real estate forms and managing disciplinary actions
questions.explanation: The REEB oversees licensing, approves forms, and handles discipline for violations.

questions.questionText: Which action violates Wisconsin real estate licensee regulations?
options: Explaining form provisions
Drafting a new form for a unique transaction
Using an attorney-prepared addendum
Reproducing approved forms with permission
questions.correctAnswer: Drafting a new form for a unique transaction
questions.explanation: Licensees cannot draft new forms; they must use approved or attorney-prepared forms.

questions.questionText: What is required for a form modification to be valid?
options: Approval from the REEB
Use of addenda or blank lines provided
Broker’s signature
A separate document outlining changes
questions.correctAnswer: Use of addenda or blank lines provided
questions.explanation: Modifications must be made using addenda or blank lines within approved forms.

questions.questionText: What is an example of "material adverse fact"?
options: A property located near a noisy area
A minor cosmetic defect
Structural damage impacting safety
A seller’s personal dispute with neighbors
questions.correctAnswer: Structural damage impacting safety
questions.explanation: Material adverse facts must affect the property’s value or safety.

questions.questionText: What is the main purpose of the WB-11 Residential Offer to Purchase?
options: To finalize the terms of sale
To initiate the negotiation process
To present a buyer’s offer in a legally binding format
To outline a buyer’s preliminary interest
questions.correctAnswer: To present a buyer’s offer in a legally binding format
questions.explanation: The WB-11 creates a legally binding offer once accepted.

questions.questionText: What distinguishes a WB-46 Multiple Counter-Proposal from a WB-44 Counter-Offer?
options: A WB-46 is binding upon delivery
A WB-46 allows negotiation with multiple buyers simultaneously
A WB-44 provides additional legal protections
A WB-44 cannot be modified after acceptance
questions.correctAnswer: A WB-46 allows negotiation with multiple buyers simultaneously
questions.explanation: A WB-46 permits non-binding proposals to multiple buyers.

questions.questionText: What happens if the seller misses the deadline to respond to an amendment?
options: The amendment is automatically accepted
The original offer remains in effect
The buyer’s offer becomes null and void
The buyer is entitled to terminate the contract
questions.correctAnswer: The original offer remains in effect
questions.explanation: If the seller does not agree, the terms of the original offer remain unchanged.

questions.questionText: What must be included in a buyer’s inspection contingency notice of defects?
options: A repair estimate
A copy of the inspection report
The buyer’s proposed remedy
A list of defects with no further documentation
questions.correctAnswer: A copy of the inspection report
questions.explanation: The inspection report must accompany the notice of defects.

questions.questionText: Under what condition does a WB-45 Cancellation Agreement and Mutual Release become effective?
options: Once signed by the buyer
Once signed by both parties
Upon approval by the REEB
When filed with the title company
questions.correctAnswer: Once signed by both parties
questions.explanation: Both parties must sign the agreement for it to be effective.

questions.questionText: What is the consequence of delivering earnest money late?
options: Automatic contract termination
A breach of contract
Seller’s option to terminate the contract
Requirement for buyer to pay penalties
questions.correctAnswer: Seller’s option to terminate the contract
questions.explanation: Late delivery of earnest money gives the seller grounds to terminate the offer.

questions.questionText: What is the impact of a protected buyer list on a new listing firm?
options: It limits the new firm’s marketing options
It prevents the new firm from earning commission from protected buyers
It requires the new firm to cooperate with the previous firm
It ensures the seller is responsible for damages caused by non-delivery
questions.correctAnswer: It prevents the new firm from earning commission from protected buyers
questions.explanation: Protected buyers are excluded from earning commissions for the new firm.

questions.questionText: When is a seller required to disclose a property defect?
options: If the buyer requests an inspection
If the defect is considered a material adverse fact
Only after the buyer’s earnest money is paid
Only when the defect impacts the property’s value
questions.correctAnswer: If the defect is considered a material adverse fact
questions.explanation: Material adverse facts must always be disclosed.

questions.questionText: What happens if a seller rejects a buyer’s notice of defects and the buyer granted no right to cure?
options: The buyer forfeits earnest money
The offer becomes null and void
The buyer must revise the notice
The seller must accept the notice
questions.correctAnswer: The offer becomes null and void
questions.explanation: Without the right to cure, the offer becomes void upon defect notice rejection.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of an addendum in a real estate transaction?
options: To clarify agency relationships
To add or modify terms not covered in the main contract
To terminate a listing agreement
To summarize the primary contract terms
questions.correctAnswer: To add or modify terms not covered in the main contract
questions.explanation: Addenda are used to add or modify terms.

questions.questionText: What defines a protected property under a WB-36 Buyer Agency Agreement?
options: A property visited by the buyer with their agent
A property previously viewed by any buyer
A property listed after the agreement is signed
A property for which the buyer submits an offer
questions.correctAnswer: A property for which the buyer submits an offer
questions.explanation: Protected properties include those where offers were submitted during the agreement term.

questions.questionText: Under what circumstance can a licensee legally line out a provision in an approved form?
options: When it reflects the client’s instructions and remains legible
When the provision is outdated or irrelevant
Upon approval by the supervising broker
If the licensee believes the provision is unnecessary
questions.correctAnswer: When it reflects the client’s instructions and remains legible
questions.explanation: Licensees can cross out provisions only when it reflects a client’s explicit instructions and the text remains legible.

questions.questionText: What happens if a buyer delivers earnest money to the wrong party?
options: The contract becomes void
The buyer forfeits the earnest money
The seller can terminate the contract
The transaction is delayed until proper payment is made
questions.correctAnswer: The transaction is delayed until proper payment is made
questions.explanation: Incorrect delivery of earnest money must be rectified to proceed, potentially delaying the transaction.

questions.questionText: What distinguishes a WB-40 Amendment from a WB-41 Notice in an inspection contingency?
options: A WB-40 changes the contract terms; a WB-41 simply notifies of an event
A WB-41 requires both parties’ agreement; a WB-40 does not
A WB-41 applies only to inspection contingencies; a WB-40 applies to all terms
A WB-40 terminates the contract if not accepted; a WB-41 does not
questions.correctAnswer: A WB-40 changes the contract terms; a WB-41 simply notifies of an event
questions.explanation: An amendment modifies terms, while a notice alerts the other party without changing the contract.

questions.questionText: How does a buyer waive their financing contingency in the WB-11 Residential Offer to Purchase?
options: By verbal agreement with the seller
Through a WB-41 Notice delivered to the seller
By crossing out the financing contingency section
Through written notice accompanied by verification of funds
questions.correctAnswer: Through written notice accompanied by verification of funds
questions.explanation: Waiving financing requires written notice and evidence of the buyer’s financial capability.

questions.questionText: What is required for a listing firm to earn commission when a protected buyer purchases the property?
options: The protected buyer must submit a new offer after the listing expires
The seller must accept the offer within one year of contract expiration
The seller must provide the protected buyer list to the new listing firm
The protected buyer must have viewed the property with the seller’s agent
questions.correctAnswer: The seller must accept the offer within one year of contract expiration
questions.explanation: Protected buyers ensure commission if they purchase within the one-year protection period.

questions.questionText: What legal standard governs the calculation of prorations at closing?
options: The seller’s estimate of current property taxes
The previous year’s tax bill unless otherwise stated
A mutually agreed percentage of the purchase price
The buyer’s financial institution’s calculation
questions.correctAnswer: The previous year’s tax bill unless otherwise stated
questions.explanation: Prorations default to the previous year’s tax bill unless specified otherwise.

questions.questionText: When does a WB-46 Multiple Counter-Proposal become a binding contract?
options: When signed by all potential buyers
Upon acceptance by one buyer and notification to the seller
When the seller selects and signs the most favorable offer
Upon delivery to the first buyer who signs the proposal
questions.correctAnswer: When the seller selects and signs the most favorable offer
questions.explanation: A WB-46 becomes binding only when the seller selects and accepts an offer.

questions.questionText: What must a buyer do if their financing is unavailable by the deadline?
options: Deliver a loan rejection notice and terminate the offer
Seek alternative financing within 30 days
Notify the seller and revise the purchase price
Request an extension from the seller in writing
questions.correctAnswer: Deliver a loan rejection notice and terminate the offer
questions.explanation: The buyer must deliver a loan rejection notice and terminate or renegotiate the offer.

questions.questionText: What is the seller’s obligation under the WB-1 Listing Contract regarding adverse facts?
options: To disclose only upon buyer inquiry
To provide written notice before accepting an offer
To disclose material adverse facts in writing at any time
To rely on the licensee to determine necessary disclosures
questions.correctAnswer: To disclose material adverse facts in writing at any time
questions.explanation: Sellers must disclose material adverse facts in writing to all parties.

questions.questionText: When is a counter-offer considered rejected?
options: Upon verbal notification from the other party
If the other party does not sign and return it by the deadline
When the other party makes a new offer
When the counter-offer is withdrawn in writing
questions.correctAnswer: If the other party does not sign and return it by the deadline
questions.explanation: A counter-offer is rejected if not signed and returned by the specified deadline.

questions.questionText: What defines a “defect” in a WB-11 Residential Offer to Purchase?
options: Any issue requiring professional repair
A condition that substantially affects property safety or value
A material adverse fact that is not disclosed
Any damage exceeding 5% of the purchase price
questions.correctAnswer: A condition that substantially affects property safety or value
questions.explanation: Defects are conditions affecting the property’s safety, value, or habitability.

questions.questionText: What must the seller provide for leased properties at closing?
options: Copies of all leases signed within the last year
Tenant contact information and lease summaries
All security deposits and prepaid rents
Written notice of lease termination
questions.correctAnswer: All security deposits and prepaid rents
questions.explanation: Security deposits and prepaid rents must be transferred to the buyer at closing.

questions.questionText: How can a seller mitigate risk from wire fraud in real estate transactions?
options: Use personal email accounts for all communications
Provide detailed wiring instructions to the buyer
Avoid electronic fund transfers entirely
Use secure communication channels for wire instructions
questions.correctAnswer: Use secure communication channels for wire instructions
questions.explanation: Secure channels reduce the risk of wire fraud in transactions.

questions.questionText: What action constitutes an unauthorized practice of law for a real estate licensee?
options: Explaining the purpose of a form
Advising on the legal effect of a contract clause
Delivering an attorney-prepared addendum
Filling in blanks on an approved form
questions.correctAnswer: Advising on the legal effect of a contract clause
questions.explanation: Licensees cannot advise on the legal implications of contract terms.

questions.questionText: Under what conditions can the Real Estate Examining Board (REEB) revoke a license?
options: Repeated failure to disclose material adverse facts
Failure to renew the license by the expiration date
Disputes with clients over commission
Using an unapproved form with client consent
questions.correctAnswer: Repeated failure to disclose material adverse facts
questions.explanation: Failure to disclose material adverse facts constitutes a serious violation warranting disciplinary action, including license revocation.

questions.questionText: How does the Wisconsin Supreme Court’s decision in the Dinger case impact licensees?
options: It limits their ability to draft contracts entirely
It permits limited legal practice through the use of approved forms
It mandates additional legal training for all licensees
It prohibits licensees from modifying approved forms
questions.correctAnswer: It permits limited legal practice through the use of approved forms
questions.explanation: The Dinger case upheld licensees’ limited ability to practice law by completing approved forms.

questions.questionText: What must a licensee ensure when using an attorney-prepared addendum?
options: The attorney’s name is identified on the addendum
The addendum is submitted for board approval
The addendum is integrated into the approved form by rewriting terms
The licensee edits the addendum to match client instructions
questions.correctAnswer: The attorney’s name is identified on the addendum
questions.explanation: Attorney-prepared addenda must include the attorney’s name for legal compliance.

questions.questionText: What is the primary purpose of the “Protected Buyer” clause in the WB-1 Residential Listing Contract?
options: To secure the seller’s ability to negotiate directly with buyers
To allow the listing firm to earn commission after contract expiration
To exclude certain buyers from being considered under the agreement
To automatically extend the listing contract for one year
questions.correctAnswer: To allow the listing firm to earn commission after contract expiration
questions.explanation: Protected buyers ensure a listing firm can earn commission for buyers introduced during the contract period.

questions.questionText: When can a licensee modify an exclusive right-to-sell listing contract into an exclusive agency agreement?
options: By mutual agreement with the buyer
Only with the seller’s attorney’s approval
By altering the WB-1 form and specifying terms
Through an addendum drafted by the listing firm
questions.correctAnswer: By altering the WB-1 form and specifying terms
questions.explanation: Modifications to create an exclusive agency listing must be made directly on the WB-1 form.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of the WB-36 Buyer Agency Agreement's exclusion of properties?
options: To clarify that certain properties will not trigger commission
To allow the buyer to negotiate directly with sellers
To ensure the buyer’s agent is not involved in certain transactions
To give the listing firm exclusive rights to specific properties
questions.correctAnswer: To clarify that certain properties will not trigger commission
questions.explanation: Excluded properties are specified to avoid commission disputes and clarify agency relationships.

questions.questionText: Under what circumstance can a licensee legally line out a provision in an approved form?
options: When it reflects the client’s instructions and remains legible
When the provision is outdated or irrelevant
Upon approval by the supervising broker
If the licensee believes the provision is unnecessary
questions.correctAnswer: When it reflects the client’s instructions and remains legible
questions.explanation: Licensees can cross out provisions only when it reflects a client’s explicit instructions and the text remains legible.

questions.questionText: What happens if a buyer delivers earnest money to the wrong party?
options: The contract becomes void
The buyer forfeits the earnest money
The seller can terminate the contract
The transaction is delayed until proper payment is made
questions.correctAnswer: The transaction is delayed until proper payment is made
questions.explanation: Incorrect delivery of earnest money must be rectified to proceed, potentially delaying the transaction.

questions.questionText: What distinguishes a WB-40 Amendment from a WB-41 Notice in an inspection contingency?
options: A WB-40 changes the contract terms; a WB-41 simply notifies of an event
A WB-41 requires both parties’ agreement; a WB-40 does not
A WB-41 applies only to inspection contingencies; a WB-40 applies to all terms
A WB-40 terminates the contract if not accepted; a WB-41 does not
questions.correctAnswer: A WB-40 changes the contract terms; a WB-41 simply notifies of an event
questions.explanation: An amendment modifies terms, while a notice alerts the other party without changing the contract.

questions.questionText: How does a buyer waive their financing contingency in the WB-11 Residential Offer to Purchase?
options: By verbal agreement with the seller
Through a WB-41 Notice delivered to the seller
By crossing out the financing contingency section
Through written notice accompanied by verification of funds
questions.correctAnswer: Through written notice accompanied by verification of funds
questions.explanation: Waiving financing requires written notice and evidence of the buyer’s financial capability.

questions.questionText: What is required for a listing firm to earn commission when a protected buyer purchases the property?
options: The protected buyer must submit a new offer after the listing expires
The seller must accept the offer within one year of contract expiration
The seller must provide the protected buyer list to the new listing firm
The protected buyer must have viewed the property with the seller’s agent
questions.correctAnswer: The seller must accept the offer within one year of contract expiration
questions.explanation: Protected buyers ensure commission if they purchase within the one-year protection period.

questions.questionText: What legal standard governs the calculation of prorations at closing?
options: The seller’s estimate of current property taxes
The previous year’s tax bill unless otherwise stated
A mutually agreed percentage of the purchase price
The buyer’s financial institution’s calculation
questions.correctAnswer: The previous year’s tax bill unless otherwise stated
questions.explanation: Prorations default to the previous year’s tax bill unless specified otherwise.

questions.questionText: When does a WB-46 Multiple Counter-Proposal become a binding contract?
options: When signed by all potential buyers
Upon acceptance by one buyer and notification to the seller
When the seller selects and signs the most favorable offer
Upon delivery to the first buyer who signs the proposal
questions.correctAnswer: When the seller selects and signs the most favorable offer
questions.explanation: A WB-46 becomes binding only when the seller selects and accepts an offer.

questions.questionText: What must a buyer do if their financing is unavailable by the deadline?
options: Deliver a loan rejection notice and terminate the offer
Seek alternative financing within 30 days
Notify the seller and revise the purchase price
Request an extension from the seller in writing
questions.correctAnswer: Deliver a loan rejection notice and terminate the offer
questions.explanation: The buyer must deliver a loan rejection notice and terminate or renegotiate the offer.

questions.questionText: What is the seller’s obligation under the WB-1 Listing Contract regarding adverse facts?
options: To disclose only upon buyer inquiry
To provide written notice before accepting an offer
To disclose material adverse facts in writing at any time
To rely on the licensee to determine necessary disclosures
questions.correctAnswer: To disclose material adverse facts in writing at any time
questions.explanation: Sellers must disclose material adverse facts in writing to all parties.

questions.questionText: When is a counter-offer considered rejected?
options: Upon verbal notification from the other party
If the other party does not sign and return it by the deadline
When the other party makes a new offer
When the counter-offer is withdrawn in writing
questions.correctAnswer: If the other party does not sign and return it by the deadline
questions.explanation: A counter-offer is rejected if not signed and returned by the specified deadline.

questions.questionText: What defines a “defect” in a WB-11 Residential Offer to Purchase?
options: Any issue requiring professional repair
A condition that substantially affects property safety or value
A material adverse fact that is not disclosed
Any damage exceeding 5% of the purchase price
questions.correctAnswer: A condition that substantially affects property safety or value
questions.explanation: Defects are conditions affecting the property’s safety, value, or habitability.

questions.questionText: What must the seller provide for leased properties at closing?
options: Copies of all leases signed within the last year
Tenant contact information and lease summaries
All security deposits and prepaid rents
Written notice of lease termination
questions.correctAnswer: All security deposits and prepaid rents
questions.explanation: Security deposits and prepaid rents must be transferred to the buyer at closing.

questions.questionText: How can a seller mitigate risk from wire fraud in real estate transactions?
options: Use personal email accounts for all communications
Provide detailed wiring instructions to the buyer
Avoid electronic fund transfers entirely
Use secure communication channels for wire instructions
questions.correctAnswer: Use secure communication channels for wire instructions
questions.explanation: Secure channels reduce the risk of wire fraud in transactions.

questions.questionText: What action constitutes an unauthorized practice of law for a real estate licensee?
options: Explaining the purpose of a form
Advising on the legal effect of a contract clause
Delivering an attorney-prepared addendum
Filling in blanks on an approved form
questions.correctAnswer: Advising on the legal effect of a contract clause
questions.explanation: Licensees cannot advise on the legal implications of contract terms.

questions.questionText: Under what conditions can the Real Estate Examining Board (REEB) revoke a license?
options: Repeated failure to disclose material adverse facts
Failure to renew the license by the expiration date
Disputes with clients over commission
Using an unapproved form with client consent
questions.correctAnswer: Repeated failure to disclose material adverse facts
questions.explanation: Failure to disclose material adverse facts constitutes a serious violation warranting disciplinary action, including license revocation.

questions.questionText: How does the Wisconsin Supreme Court’s decision in the Dinger case impact licensees?
options: It limits their ability to draft contracts entirely
It permits limited legal practice through the use of approved forms
It mandates additional legal training for all licensees
It prohibits licensees from modifying approved forms
questions.correctAnswer: It permits limited legal practice through the use of approved forms
questions.explanation: The Dinger case upheld licensees’ limited ability to practice law by completing approved forms.

questions.questionText: What must a licensee ensure when using an attorney-prepared addendum?
options: The attorney’s name is identified on the addendum
The addendum is submitted for board approval
The addendum is integrated into the approved form by rewriting terms
The licensee edits the addendum to match client instructions
questions.correctAnswer: The attorney’s name is identified on the addendum
questions.explanation: Attorney-prepared addenda must include the attorney’s name for legal compliance.

questions.questionText: What is the primary purpose of the “Protected Buyer” clause in the WB-1 Residential Listing Contract?
options: To secure the seller’s ability to negotiate directly with buyers
To allow the listing firm to earn commission after contract expiration
To exclude certain buyers from being considered under the agreement
To automatically extend the listing contract for one year
questions.correctAnswer: To allow the listing firm to earn commission after contract expiration
questions.explanation: Protected buyers ensure a listing firm can earn commission for buyers introduced during the contract period.

questions.questionText: When can a licensee modify an exclusive right-to-sell listing contract into an exclusive agency agreement?
options: By mutual agreement with the buyer
Only with the seller’s attorney’s approval
By altering the WB-1 form and specifying terms
Through an addendum drafted by the listing firm
questions.correctAnswer: By altering the WB-1 form and specifying terms
questions.explanation: Modifications to create an exclusive agency listing must be made directly on the WB-1 form.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of the WB-36 Buyer Agency Agreement's exclusion of properties?
options: To clarify that certain properties will not trigger commission
To allow the buyer to negotiate directly with sellers
To ensure the buyer’s agent is not involved in certain transactions
To give the listing firm exclusive rights to specific properties
questions.correctAnswer: To clarify that certain properties will not trigger commission
questions.explanation: Excluded properties are specified to avoid commission disputes and clarify agency relationships.

options: When it reflects the client’s instructions and remains legible
When the provision is outdated or irrelevant
Upon approval by the supervising broker
If the licensee believes the provision is unnecessary
questions.correctAnswer: When it reflects the client’s instructions and remains legible
questions.explanation: Licensees can cross out provisions only when it reflects a client’s explicit instructions and the text remains legible.

questions.questionText: What happens if a buyer delivers earnest money to the wrong party?
options: The contract becomes void
The buyer forfeits the earnest money
The seller can terminate the contract
The transaction is delayed until proper payment is made
questions.correctAnswer: The transaction is delayed until proper payment is made
questions.explanation: Incorrect delivery of earnest money must be rectified to proceed, potentially delaying the transaction.

questions.questionText: What distinguishes a WB-40 Amendment from a WB-41 Notice in an inspection contingency?
options: A WB-40 changes the contract terms; a WB-41 simply notifies of an event
A WB-41 requires both parties’ agreement; a WB-40 does not
A WB-41 applies only to inspection contingencies; a WB-40 applies to all terms
A WB-40 terminates the contract if not accepted; a WB-41 does not
questions.correctAnswer: A WB-40 changes the contract terms; a WB-41 simply notifies of an event
questions.explanation: An amendment modifies terms, while a notice alerts the other party without changing the contract.

questions.questionText: How does a buyer waive their financing contingency in the WB-11 Residential Offer to Purchase?
options: By verbal agreement with the seller
Through a WB-41 Notice delivered to the seller
By crossing out the financing contingency section
Through written notice accompanied by verification of funds
questions.correctAnswer: Through written notice accompanied by verification of funds
questions.explanation: Waiving financing requires written notice and evidence of the buyer’s financial capability.
